content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The solution to this problem is very intuitive. I think this is a great problem as a puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Author has listened to feedback and corrected any misunderstandings there may have been.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good varieties of test cases covering all kinds of inputs I expect.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

I have to pay double caution in understanding the phrase "right lane". It can mean the correct lane, or can mean the lane on the right-hand-side.

Another obstacle is to understand what is "R". If a person (a peon in the game) is facing West, his right-hand-side is North. "R" depends on what direction a person is facing. At the beginning I was at lost about all the direction things. The statement alone was not sufficient to help understanding until I browse the test cases. Any chance this can be improved?

Hi, I think the word "first" in 1 is a bit confusing.
It can mean we have to resolve 1 entirely before going to 2, but the 3 point may be in contradiction with it.

Just my point of view, otherwise a very interesting puzzle ;)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Thanks for a very nice exercise for simulation! (solved in Java)
The only thing I would change is the description of how the rings should be dealt with. Took me a while to figure it out. However, as written in the comments below, it can be part of the puzzle to find it out what the proper behavior should be. After all, studying the test cases can say a lot :-)

This is kind of implicitly included in rule 3, and there are test cases for it, but I'd probably also explicitely mention, that rule 3 blocks lane changing, even if along the given environment it prevents both people's movements E.g:
oRLLO
oRRLo
Is a congestion, because the middle ones cannot change lanes due to rule 3. But one could argue, that since the ones on the sides do not really have any chance of moving there either way, the "prority" given by rule 3 cannot be applied and thus the lane changers in this case can go on like
oRRLo
oRLLo
Which can be finished intuitively

A quite nice little simulation :)
It would be cool to also have some alternative versions with e.g.:
- roadblocks
- more lanes
- 2d map with people walking all directions

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
this puzzle looks cool, I'd suggest giving it another chance

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The solution to this problem is very intuitive. I think this is a great problem as a puzzle.
Awesome puzzle!

Great puzzle! I'm a little confused as to when you can move to a previously occupied space (rule 6).

If you have this situation:
o o R L o

Then I can apply rule 6 to make the next state become:
o o L R o

I think the decision making part of the next direction a person will move to should be clearer. Then, those who are trapped will become roadblocks where rule 6 cannot be applied.
Thanks for checking out my puzzle. If you have any ideas for how to improve it, I would love to hear them :)
That situation is covered by rule 7. The R and L cannot swap places with each other because they are in the same lane.

Hey, thanks for approving my puzzle 3 months ago! Do you mind approving it again? Unfortunately, approvals get reset every 30 days. Contacting you in this way was the action recommended to me by [CG]Thibaud (you can see our discussion in the comments above).

Thanks! By the way, I was wondering, is there a good reason why approvals for contributions get reset when you resubmit a contribution (like I did)? One person approved mine, but it's back at 0 again, and I doubt the same person is going to look at this puzzle again (because they think they already approved it). I didn't even know that's how it works until this happened, so I assume most others don't know either.
Totally. I thought the same, but it's pretty hard already (for me at least!), and I'm waiting for approval on this one before making a more complex version :)

I think it's clear already. If they switch lanes, that means they took priority over the forward movers. But rule 3 explicitly prohibits this. Therefore, it's congestion.

I think part of the fun of this is not making everything explicit; you have to correctly infer from the given rules what does and doesn't lead to contradictions.
Thanks! I did create the test cases to cover every possible "type" of scenario :)
I changed the wording, let me know what you think!

Thanks for the feedback! I changed "right" to "correct".

I'm not sure I understand what is causing the confusion with "R". I write that R moves to the right, and as in the example:

o o R L o
o L R o o

I lay out the path horizontally, so it seems clear that right means -> and R moves in that direction. "Right" is not relative to the direction a pedestrian is facing (which is never mentioned, to avoid confusion) but relative to our perspective looking at the path.

> I'm not sure I understand what is causing the confusion with "R".

The confusion (at least to me) comes from misunderstanding from whose viewpoint to define the "Right" side. Now I know that it is from the reader's viewpoint (i.e. myself).  At first I though it was from each peon's viewpoint, and the peons are walking in different directions so that the Left and Right of each peon can be different.

I struggled a bit to understand the meaning before giving up.
Do you think I should include something like "(from you, reader's perspective)"?
Not sure is it the best approach (too wordy and odd). Ideally there is a graphic showing where is the Left and Right sides, and how the people flow. An ASCII graphic may work.

How about the following above the examples?

Left <--------------> Right

To make clear that the directions are associated with the path, not the individual pedestrians.

......................o o o o o ---> Right exit
Left exit <--- o o o o o

perhaps like this (I have to use dots to fill up the space in this box) to indicate there are two one-way lanes
Thanks, I added it to the description!
You can remove the dots in the statements. I added them just because this message area does not have monospace formatting.

Yeah, I tried that but it deletes spaces and collapses to 

o o o o o ---> Right exit
Left exit <--- o o o o o

let me edit it
this is a trick that not many people know.
Amazing! Thank you sir
Much better thanks, I will try the puzzle soon.

Hey, thanks for approving my puzzle last month! Do you mind approving it again? Unfortunately, approvals get reset every 30 days. Contacting you in this way was the action recommended to me by [CG]Thibaud (you can see our discussion in the comments below).
I guess that we wanted to restart from scratch in case the puzzle is modified by the author. But I agree, it's a little weird. At least the comment stays and can help other mods making up their mind

I now have three approvals, but they all took place in different months. The puzzle was barely changed (only the wording), so the approvals aren't of different versions. I believe the reason that it has taken so long to obtain three approvals is because the difficulty of this puzzle is "hard". It's reasonable to assume that relatively fewer people actually tried to solve this puzzle for that reason, and thus there is a smaller pool of people who are able to approve it. It therefore makes sense that the approvals are spread out. Personally, I don't see any merit in requiring three approvals in the span of a single month. I have addressed all criticisms, and the overall evaluation appears to be clearly positive (+18). So I think this puzzle is ready to be accepted. What are your thoughts?

I agree. There's an issue with the moderation of hard puzzles.

I'll add it to the list of issues we'll be trying to tackle in the following months.

Meanwhile, I suggest pinging the people who validated your puzzle in the past to get another approval from them. (replying to their message should trigger a notification on their side)
Hey mate, surely i'll re-approve!
